perturbation.original_text: By either Vendor or Distributor, following a material or continuing breach of this Agreement (in the case of a breach which is capable of remedy) by the other party and the breaching party's failure to cure such breach within ninety (90) days of receiving written notice of such breach, where a breach shall be considered capable of remedy if the party in breach can comply with the provision in question in all respects other than as to the time of the performance (provided that the time of performance is not of the essence); or
perturbation.changed_text: By either Vendor or Distributor, following a material or continuing breach of this Agreement (in the case of a breach which is capable of remedy) by the other party and the breaching party's failure to cure such breach within ten (10) days of receiving written notice of such breach, where a breach shall be considered capable of remedy if the party in breach can comply with the provision in question in all respects other than as to the time of the performance (provided that the time of performance is not of the essence); or
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for a 90-day cure period for a breach of contract. This has been reduced to 10 days. Depending on the nature of the breach and the jurisdiction (Ontario, Canada), this cure period may be deemed unreasonably short, particularly for complex breaches, and a court may not enforce such a short period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding reasonable cure periods for breaches.

perturbation.original_text: Distributor may return Products to Vendor for credit or full reimbursement, as the case may be, only pursuant to this Section 8.
perturbation.changed_text: Distributor may return Products to Vendor for credit or full reimbursement, as the case may be, only pursuant to this Section 8. All returns must be made within 5 days of receipt.
perturbation.explanation: This change adds a strict 5-day return window. Depending on the complexity of the product and the location of the distributor (London), a 5-day window for inspection and return could be deemed commercially unreasonable, especially if latent defects are present, which are not easily discovered, potentially conflicting with consumer protection laws and general contract principles requiring reasonable time for inspection and rejection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding reasonable time for inspection and rejection of goods. Consumer Protection Act depending on product and jurisdiction.
